text: Who is the primary author of 2 Corinthians?
verseText: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, and Timothy our brother, To the church of God that is at Corinth, with all the saints who are in the whole of Achaia:

text: Compared to 1 Corinthians, 2 Corinthians is generally considered more...
verseText: For I wrote to you out of much affliction and anguish of heart and with many tears, not to cause you pain but to let you know the abundant love that I have for you. And, apart from other things, there is the daily pressure on me of my anxiety for all the churches. Who is weak, and I am not weak? Who is made to fall, and I am not indignant?

text: In 2 Corinthians 1, Paul speaks about the comfort God gives in affliction so that believers can do what?
options: Comfort others who are in affliction
verseText: Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies and God of all comfort, who comforts us in all our affliction, so that we may be able to comfort those who are in any affliction, with the comfort with which we ourselves are comforted by God.

text: What ministry does Paul describe in 2 Corinthians 3, contrasting it with the ministry of the Old Covenant?
options: The ministry of the Spirit / righteousness / the New Covenant
verseText: who has made us sufficient to be ministers of a new covenant, not of the letter but of the Spirit. For the letter kills, but the Spirit gives life... For if there was glory in the ministry of condemnation, the ministry of righteousness must far exceed it in glory.

text: According to 2 Corinthians 4:7, believers have the treasure of the gospel in what kind of vessels?
verseText: But we have this treasure in jars of clay, to show that the surpassing power belongs to God and not to us.

text: What ministry has been given to believers, according to 2 Corinthians 5:18-20?
verseText: All this is from God, who through Christ reconciled us to himself and gave us the ministry of reconciliation; that is, in Christ God was reconciling the world to himself, not counting their trespasses against them, and entrusting to us the message of reconciliation.

text: In 2 Corinthians 6:14, Paul warns believers not to be unequally yoked with whom?
verseText: Do not be unequally yoked with unbelievers. For what partnership has righteousness with lawlessness? Or what fellowship has light with darkness?

text: Chapters 8 and 9 of 2 Corinthians primarily encourage the Corinthians regarding what?
options: Generous giving to help needy believers in Jerusalem
verseText: But as you excel in everything—in faith, in speech, in knowledge, in all earnestness, and in our love for you—see that you excel in this act of grace also. The point is this: whoever sows sparingly will also reap sparingly, and whoever sows bountifully will also reap bountifully. Each one must give as he has decided in his heart, not reluctantly or under compulsion, for God loves a cheerful giver.

text: In 2 Corinthians 10-13, Paul defends his apostleship against opponents he sarcastically calls what?
verseText: Indeed, I consider that I am not in the least inferior to these super-apostles. I have been a fool! You forced me to it, for I ought to have been commended by you. For I was not at all inferior to these super-apostles, even though I am nothing.

text: What did Paul ask God three times to remove from him, which he referred to as a 'thorn in the flesh' (2 Corinthians 12)?
verseText: So to keep me from becoming conceited because of the surpassing greatness of the revelations, a thorn was given me in the flesh, a messenger of Satan to harass me, to keep me from becoming conceited. Three times I pleaded with the Lord about this, that it should leave me. But he said to me, “My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.” Therefore I will boast all the more gladly of my weaknesses, so that the power of Christ may rest upon me.

text: Paul mentions a previous 'painful visit' and a 'severe letter' written out of anguish. What emotion motivated him to write that letter?
options: Great affliction and anguish, with many tears, to show his love
verseText: For I made up my mind not to make another painful visit to you. For if I cause you pain, who is there to make me glad but the one whom I have pained? And I wrote as I did, so that when I came I might not suffer pain from those who should have made me rejoice, for I felt sure of all of you, that my joy would be the joy of you all. For I wrote to you out of much affliction and anguish of heart and with many tears, not to cause you pain but to let you know the abundant love that I have for you.

text: Regarding the man who caused pain (likely the offender from 1 Corinthians 5), what does Paul now urge the Corinthians to do?
options: Forgive, comfort, and reaffirm their love for him
verseText: For such a one, this punishment by the majority is enough, so you should rather turn to forgive and comfort him, or he may be overwhelmed by excessive sorrow. So I beg you to reaffirm your love for him.

text: Paul describes his ministry and that of his companions as spreading what aroma in every place?
verseText: But thanks be to God, who in Christ always leads us in triumphal procession, and through us spreads the fragrance of the knowledge of him everywhere. For we are the aroma of Christ to God among those who are being saved and among those who are perishing,

text: In contrasting the Old and New Covenants, Paul mentions a veil over Moses' face. What does he say happens when one turns to the Lord?
verseText: But when one turns to the Lord, the veil is removed.

text: Paul states that the god of this world has done what to the minds of unbelievers?
options: Blinded them to keep them from seeing the light of the gospel
verseText: In their case the god of this world has blinded the minds of the unbelievers, to keep them from seeing the light of the gospel of the glory of Christ, who is the image of God.

text: Despite facing afflictions, perplexity, and persecution, what does Paul say is NOT happening to him and his companions?
options: They are not crushed, driven to despair, or forsaken
verseText: We are afflicted in every way, but not crushed; perplexed, but not driven to despair; persecuted, but not forsaken; struck down, but not destroyed;

text: Paul looks forward to a future dwelling, contrasting our earthly 'tent' with what?
options: A building from God, an eternal house in heaven
verseText: For we know that if the tent that is our earthly home is destroyed, we have a building from God, a house not made with hands, eternal in the heavens.

text: What motivates Paul's ministry, knowing that all must appear before the judgment seat of Christ?
verseText: For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, so that each one may receive what is due for what he has done in the body, whether good or evil. Therefore, knowing the fear of the Lord, we persuade others.

text: What transformation does Paul say occurs when someone is 'in Christ'?
options: They are freed from all suffering
verseText: Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation. The old has passed away; behold, the new has come.

text: As ambassadors for Christ, what appeal does Paul make on Christ's behalf?
verseText: Therefore, we are ambassadors for Christ, God making his appeal through us. We implore you on behalf of Christ, be reconciled to God.

text: Paul describes his apostolic ministry as being approved through endurance in hardships, beatings, imprisonments, and tumults, often appearing as sorrowful, poor, and having nothing, yet possessing what?
options: Always rejoicing, making many rich, and possessing everything
verseText: but as servants of God we commend ourselves in every way: by great endurance, in afflictions, hardships, calamities, beatings, imprisonments, riots, labors, sleepless nights, hunger; by purity, knowledge, patience, kindness, the Holy Spirit, genuine love; by truthful speech, and the power of God; with the weapons of righteousness for the right hand and for the left; through honor and dishonor, through slander and praise. We are treated as impostors, and yet are true; as unknown, and yet well known; as dying, and behold, we live; as punished, and yet not killed; as sorrowful, yet always rejoicing; as poor, yet making many rich; as having nothing, yet possessing everything.

text: After urging separation from unbelievers, what does Paul call the Corinthians to do regarding holiness?
options: Cleanse themselves from defilement and perfect holiness in the fear of God
verseText: Since we have these promises, beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from every defilement of body and spirit, bringing holiness to completion in the fear of God.

text: Paul rejoiced greatly upon Titus's return because Titus reported what about the Corinthians?
options: Their longing, mourning, and zeal for Paul
verseText: and not only by his coming but also by the comfort with which he was comforted by you, as he told us of your longing, your mourning, your zeal for me, so that I rejoiced still more. For see what earnestness this godly grief has produced in you, what eagerness to clear yourselves, what indignation, what fear, what longing, what zeal, what punishment! At every point you have proved yourselves innocent in the matter.

text: What kind of grief does Paul commend, contrasting it with worldly grief?
options: Godly grief that produces repentance leading to salvation
verseText: For godly grief produces a repentance that leads to salvation without regret, whereas worldly grief produces death.

text: Paul uses the example of which churches to motivate the Corinthians' giving, highlighting their generosity despite extreme poverty?
verseText: We want you to know, brothers, about the grace of God that has been given among the churches of Macedonia, for in a severe test of affliction, their abundance of joy and their extreme poverty have overflowed in a wealth of generosity on their part.

text: What ultimate example of giving does Paul point to in 2 Corinthians 8?
options: The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, who became poor for our sake
verseText: For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that though he was rich, yet for your sake he became poor, so that you by his poverty might become rich.

text: What principle does Paul state regarding the attitude behind giving?
options: Give only if you expect something in return
Give cheerfully, not reluctantly or under compulsion
Give only to those who can repay you
verseText: Each one must give as he has decided in his heart, not reluctantly or under compulsion, for God loves a cheerful giver.

text: Paul states that generous giving will result in thanksgiving to whom?
verseText: You will be enriched in every way to be generous in every way, which through us will produce thanksgiving to God. For the ministry of this service is not only supplying the needs of the saints but is also overflowing in many thanksgivings to God.

text: Though Paul lives in the flesh, what does he say about the weapons of his warfare?
options: They have divine power to destroy strongholds
verseText: For though we walk in the flesh, we are not waging war according to the flesh. For the weapons of our warfare are not of the flesh but have divine power to destroy strongholds.

text: What kind of 'strongholds' does Paul mention his spiritual weapons are designed to destroy?
options: Arguments and lofty opinions raised against the knowledge of God
verseText: For the weapons of our warfare are not of the flesh but have divine power to destroy strongholds. We destroy arguments and every lofty opinion raised against the knowledge of God, and take every thought captive to obey Christ,

text: Paul expresses concern that the Corinthians might be led astray from a sincere and pure devotion to Christ, just as who was deceived by the serpent?
verseText: But I am afraid that as the serpent deceived Eve by his cunning, your thoughts will be led astray from a sincere and pure devotion to Christ.

text: How did the 'super-apostles' apparently differ from Paul in their approach to receiving support from the Corinthians?
options: They accepted support (and likely demanded it)
verseText: Or did I commit a sin in humbling myself so that you might be exalted, because I preached God's gospel to you free of charge? For you bear it if someone makes slaves of you, or devours you, or takes advantage of you, or puts on airs, or strikes you in the face.

text: Paul sarcastically suggests he was inferior to the 'super-apostles' in what area, contrasting it with his own practice?
verseText: Or did I commit a sin in humbling myself so that you might be exalted, because I preached God's gospel to you free of charge? I robbed other churches by accepting support from them in order to serve you. And when I was with you and was in need, I did not burden anyone, for the brothers who came from Macedonia supplied my need. So I refrained and will refrain from burdening you in any way. For in what were you less favored than the other churches, except that I myself did not burden you? Forgive me this wrong!

text: Paul lists numerous hardships he endured for the gospel (imprisonments, beatings, shipwrecks, dangers). What daily pressure does he also mention?
verseText: Are they servants of Christ? I am a better one—I am talking like a madman—with far greater labors, far more imprisonments, with countless beatings, and often near death. Five times I received at the hands of the Jews the forty lashes less one. Three times I was beaten with rods. Once I was stoned. Three times I was shipwrecked; a night and a day I was adrift at sea; on frequent journeys, in danger from rivers, danger from robbers, danger from my own people, danger from Gentiles, danger in the city, danger in the wilderness, danger at sea, danger from false brothers; in toil and hardship, through many a sleepless night, in hunger and thirst, often without food, in cold and exposure. And, apart from other things, there is the daily pressure on me of my anxiety for all the churches.

text: If Paul must boast, what does he say he will boast about?
options: The things that show his weakness
verseText: If I must boast, I will boast of the things that show my weakness... But on my own behalf I will not boast, except of my weaknesses.

text: Paul recounts being let down in a basket through a window in which city to escape?
verseText: At Damascus, the governor under King Aretas was guarding the city of Damascus in order to seize me, but I was let down in a basket through a window in the wall and escaped his hands.

text: Paul speaks of visions and revelations, including being caught up to where?
verseText: I know a man in Christ who fourteen years ago was caught up to the third heaven—whether in the body or out of the body I do not know, God knows. And I know that this man was caught up into paradise—whether in the body or out of the body I do not know, God knows—and he heard things that cannot be told, which man may not utter.

text: What was God's response to Paul's repeated prayer regarding the 'thorn in the flesh'?
options: 'My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.'
verseText: But he said to me, “My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.” Therefore I will boast all the more gladly of my weaknesses, so that the power of Christ may rest upon me.

text: Because God's power is perfected in weakness, Paul states he is content with what?
options: Weaknesses, insults, hardships, persecutions, and calamities
verseText: For the sake of Christ, then, I am content with weaknesses, insults, hardships, persecutions, and calamities. For when I am weak, then I am strong.

text: Paul performed 'signs and wonders and mighty works' among the Corinthians, which he refers to as the marks of what?
verseText: The signs of a true apostle were performed among you with utmost patience, with signs and wonders and mighty works.

text: Paul expresses fear that when he visits Corinth again, he might find them engaged in what kinds of behaviors?
options: Quarreling, jealousy, anger, hostility, slander, gossip, conceit, and disorder
verseText: For I fear that perhaps when I come I may find you not as I wish, and that you may find me not as you wish—that perhaps there may be quarreling, jealousy, anger, hostility, slander, gossip, conceit, and disorder.

text: What does Paul urge the Corinthians to do before his arrival to avoid facing severe judgment?
options: Examine themselves to see if they are in the faith
verseText: Examine yourselves, to see whether you are in the faith. Test yourselves. Or do you not realize this about yourselves, that Jesus Christ is in you?—unless indeed you fail to meet the test!

text: Paul states that he and his companions can do nothing against what, but only for it?
verseText: For we cannot do anything against the truth, but only for the truth.

text: What is Paul's prayer for the Corinthians, mentioned near the end of the letter?
options: That they all speak in tongues
verseText: For we are glad when we are weak and you are strong. Your restoration is what we pray for. Finally, brothers, rejoice. Aim for restoration, comfort one another, agree with one another, live in peace; and the God of love and peace will be with you.

text: What final instruction does Paul give regarding greetings?
options: Greet one another with a holy kiss
verseText: Greet one another with a holy kiss.

text: The concluding verse (2 Cor 13:14) is a well-known benediction invoking whom?
options: The Lord Jesus Christ, God (the Father), and the Holy Spirit
verseText: The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ and the love of God and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all.

text: Who does Paul mention is with him in the opening greeting besides himself?
verseText: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, and Timothy our brother, To the church of God that is at Corinth, with all the saints who are in the whole of Achaia:

text: Paul explains a change in his travel plans, assuring the Corinthians his 'yes' is not 'yes and no'. He emphasizes the certainty found in whom?
verseText: As surely as God is faithful, our word to you has not been Yes and No. For the Son of God, Jesus Christ, whom we proclaimed among you, Silvanus and Timothy and I, was not Yes and No, but in him it is always Yes. For all the promises of God find their Yes in him. That is why it is through him that we utter our Amen to God for his glory.

text: Who does Paul say establishes believers and has anointed them, putting His seal on them?
verseText: And it is God who establishes us with you in Christ, and has anointed us, and who has also put his seal on us and given us his Spirit in our hearts as a guarantee.

text: Paul contrasts the 'ministry of death, carved in letters on stone' with the ministry of the Spirit. What characteristic marked the ministry of death despite its fading glory?
options: It came with glory (so that Israelites couldn't gaze at Moses' face)
verseText: Now if the ministry of death, carved in letters on stone, came with such glory that the Israelites could not gaze at Moses' face because of its glory, which was being brought to an end,

text: Where the Spirit of the Lord is, what does Paul say there is?
verseText: Now the Lord is the Spirit, and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom.

text: Believers, with unveiled faces, behold the glory of the Lord and are being transformed into what?
options: The same image from one degree of glory to another
verseText: And we all, with unveiled face, beholding the glory of the Lord, are being transformed into the same image from one degree of glory to another. For this comes from the Lord who is the Spirit.

text: Paul emphasizes that he preaches not himself, but whom?
verseText: For what we proclaim is not ourselves, but Jesus Christ as Lord, with ourselves as your servants for Jesus' sake.

text: Paul connects present, momentary affliction with preparing believers for what?
options: An eternal weight of glory beyond all comparison
verseText: For this light momentary affliction is preparing for us an eternal weight of glory beyond all comparison,

text: While in our earthly bodies ('at home in the body'), Paul says we are away from whom?
verseText: So we are always of good courage. We know that while we are at home in the body we are away from the Lord,

text: How does Paul say believers currently live, in contrast to living by sight?
verseText: for we walk by faith, not by sight.

text: What is Paul's stated ambition, whether at home in the body or away from it?
verseText: So whether we are at home or away, we make it our aim to please him.

text: Paul describes the exchange that happened for believers: Christ became sin so that believers might become what?
options: The righteousness of God in Him
verseText: For our sake he made him to be sin who knew no sin, so that in him we might become the righteousness of God.

text: Paul urges the Corinthians not to receive God's grace in what way?
verseText: Working together with him, then, we appeal to you not to receive the grace of God in vain.

text: What relationship does Paul affirm between believers and God, quoting the Old Testament, after warning against being yoked with unbelievers?
options: 'I will be a father to you, and you shall be sons and daughters to me'
verseText: Therefore go out from their midst, and be separate from them, says the Lord, and touch no unclean thing; then I will welcome you, and I will be a father to you, and you shall be my sons and daughters, says the Lord Almighty.
